The form that this case takes depends on the last letter of the preceding syllable: གིས་, གྱིས་, ཀྱིས་, ས་, ཡིས་, and the archaic form འིས་ (xxlink MST 8.4).

The case functions of this marker are practically identical in the Literary and Standard Tibetan. The agentive indicates the agent, the instrument, the cause and the manner, and forms adverbs.

The applications listed below are limited to the literary language.

The marker གིས་ is sometimes used as a connective by being directly appended to a verb. The translation will vary according to context: “and,” “after,” “because.”

  • ཁོང་གཉིས་ཕྱིར་ལོག་གིས་ཆུ་ཚོད་གཅིག་སོང་རྗེས་ཡང་བསྐྱར་ཡོང་། “The two of them went back and returned an hour later.”

In Literary Tibetan, the agentive marker is often associated with the nominalizer པ་ (or its variant བ་): པས་. This marker also operates as a connective, and depending on the context may be translated as “and,” “after,” “because,” or “since.” It generally introduces comparative clauses (rather like the ablative ལས་).

  • མིག་གི་དབང་པོ་ཉམས་པས་ཐག་རིང་དང་ཆུང་བའི་གཟུགས་མི་ཐོང་། “Because the sense of sight has been impaired, far-off and small shapes are not seen.”
  • བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས་ཀྱི་དྲུང་དུ་ཕྱིན་པས་ཁྱོད་ཀྱིས་ལྷ་ཡུལ་མཐོང་ངམ་གསུངས། “He went before the Bhagavan and (the latter) said (to him), ‘Have you seen the divine realm?’”
  • མཆིལ་བའི་ཤ་ལ་ཆགས་པ་ཡིས་ཉ་རྣམས་དེ་མ་ཐག་དུ་གསོད། “Because of their desire for bait, fish are immediately killed.”
  • རང་གི་ལུས་འདི་རྣག་ཁྲག་ཆུ་སེར་གྱི་རྐྱལ་པ་ཡིན་པས་གཅེས་པར་མ་འཛིན། “Because your body is a bag of pus, blood, and lymph, don’t become attached to it.”
  • རྒྱབ་མདུན་གང་ནས་བལྟས་ཀྱང་ཀུན་བས་མཛེས། “Whether you see her from behind or from in front, she is lovelier than anyone.”
  • ཀློག་པ་བས་ཀྱང་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་བསྐོམ་པ། “Rather than reading, (it would be better to) practice samādhi meditation.”
